ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills in Modern Hebrew.
Hebrew 120 will give you a solid knowledge of the past tense and expand your vocab greatly, helping you to speak more fluently about a variety of topics
improved speaking skills in Modern Hebrew
We learned the partial past tense.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: course material, weekly vocabulary lists, nice Professor.
Weaknesses: not enough speaking interaction with the class, the Professor could have pushed much harder in terms of forcing students to speak only in Hebrew, as a result I do not think my speaking abilities improved as much as they could have.
Hebrew is super fun and pretty low stress, especially with Orit!

Classroom activities were fun, but assignments were poorly organized and didn't cover new material systematically. Verbs were taught well, but I also wished we had a more systematic way to practice vocabulary and other grammar points together.

Strengths: It's fun to be in class with friends!
Weaknesses: You don't learn a lot.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to learn modern Hebrew then go for it. I do not think it should be taken just to fulfill the language requirement (if you want that then go take Indonesian or something), but rather for those who truly want to learn the Hebrew language.
Definitely take if you want to learn hebrew!
It's fun and it's good for maintenance of the Hebrew speaking skills you acquired in L1 with a few gains in vocabulary and verbs, but not the same tight organization and rapid growth I saw in L1.
I mean it's a fun course if ya wanna learn Hebrew. I don't like the asynchronous days at all, and my engagement with the class really fell off a cliff after spring break.
